No, no, ye Romans, we have ways to scape you
To make you poor again, indeed our Prisoners,
And stick our Triumphs full.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: D'ye wonder we'll make our Monuments
In spight of Fortune, in spight of all
Your Eagles Wings? We'll work a pitch above ye.

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: Decius, go Charge the Breach.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Stick in thy Body, and make it good but half an hour.

sp.speaker: Nenn.
sp.l: I'll do't.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: And then be sure to Die.

sp.speaker: Nenn.
sp.l: It shall go hard else.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Farewel, brave Nennius, we shall meet yonder,
Where few of those must come.
Bring up the Poison.

sp.speaker: Bonv.
sp.l: O my Fortune!

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Hah! What said you?

sp.speaker: Bonv.
sp.l: Good Mother, nothing to offend you.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Here, Girl: behold us, Romans.

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: Mercy yet.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: No Talking, come, short Prayers, and let's dispatch
The Business. You begin, shrink not.
I'll see you do't.

sp.speaker: Bonv.
sp.l: O Gentle Mother!
O Romans! O my Heart! I dare not.

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: Woman! Woman! Unnatural Woman!

sp.speaker: Bonv.
sp.l: O! perswade her Romans: Alas I am Young,
And wou'd Live, Noble Mother. Can you kill
That you gave Life to? Are my Years
Fit for Destruction?

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: Yield, and be a Queen still, a Mother and a Friend.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Ye talk in vain, come Drink it.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Fie, Sister, fie! What wou'd you live to be?

sp.speaker: Bonv.
sp.l: Mercy. O Mercy!

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: Hear her, thou wretched Woman.

sp.speaker: Bonv.
sp.l: Mercy, Mother! O whither will ye send me?
I was once your Darling. Your Delight.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: O Gods! Fear in my Family? Do it, and Nobly.

sp.speaker: Bonv.
sp.l: O! Do not frown then.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Do it, Worthy Sister.
'Tis nothing; 'tis but a Pleasure; we'll go with you.

sp.speaker: Bonv.
sp.l: O! If I knew but whither!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: To the Bless'd above, where we shall meet our Father,
Where nothing but true Joy is.

sp.speaker: Bonv.
sp.l: O! Comfort me still for Heavens sake.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: No Wars, no Lustful Slaves to Ravish us.

sp.speaker: Bonv.
sp.l: That steals me along; farewel to this World.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: That's my Good Girl.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: The next is mine.
Show me a Roman Lady in all your Stories
Dare do this for her Honour?

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Make haste.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: I will. Wou'd you learn how to Die bravely, Romans;
To fling off this Case of Flesh, lose all your Cares
For ever, hunt Honour and not Nations with your Sword:
Keep your Minds humble, your Devotions high,
So shall you learn the Noblest part, to Die.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: I come, my Noble Children, here,
Here's the Draught wou'd ask no less than Caesar's self
To pledge it for the Glories sake.

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: Madam, make up your own Conditions.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: So we will.

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: Stay, be any thing.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: A Saint, Suetonius, when thou shalt fear and Die
Like a Slave; ye Fools, you shou'd have ty'd
Up Death first when ye Conquered.
You sweat for us in vain else, see him here,
He's ours still, and our Friend Laughs at your Pities;
And we command him with as easie Reins
As do our Enemies. I feel the Poison.
Poor Vanquisht Romans, with what matchless
Tortures cou'd I now Rack you, but I pity ye,
Desiring to Die quiet; nay, so much
I hate to prosecute my Victory,
That I will give you Counsel e're I Die,
If you will keep your Laws and Empire whole,
Place in your Romans Flesh, a British Soul.

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: Desperate and Strange!
Give her fair Funeral, she was Noble, and a Queen.
Petilius haste, draw out three Companies,
And make up instantly to Caratach.
What means this Ceremony?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: The Body of Young Junius, that was
Slain in the last Battle.

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: Go then Petilius, do as I commanded.
After due Ceremony done to th' Dead,
The Noble Dead, we'll follow you.

div.stage: Enter Caratach upon a Rock, and Hengo by him Sleeping.

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: Thus we Afflicted Britains climb for Safeties,
And to avoid our Dangers seek Destructions.
Thus we awake to Sorrows, O thou Woman!
Thou Agent for Adversities! What Curses
This Day belong to thy Improvidence?
To Britans, by thy means? What sad Millions
Of Widows weeping Eyes? The Strong Man's Valour
Thou hast betray'd to Fury; the Childs Fortune
To fear and want of Friends, whose Pieties
Might wipe his Mournings off, and build his Sorrows
A House of Rest by his Blest Ancestors.
The Virgins thou hast robb'd of all their Wishes,
Blasted their blowing hopes, turn'd their Songs,
Their Mirthful Marriage Songs, to Funerals,
The Land thou hast left a Wilderness of Wretches.
The Boy begins to stir, thy safety made,
Wou'd my Soul were in Heaven.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: O Noble Uncle! Look out, I dreamt we were betray'd.

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: No harm Boy, 'tis but thy Emptiness, that breeds
These Fancies, thou sha't have Meat anon.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: A little, Uncle, and I shall hold out bravely.

div.stage: Enter Macer and Soldiers with Meat and a Bottle.

sp.speaker: Macer.
sp.l: Hang it o'th' side o'th' Rock, as tho' the Britains
Stole hither to Relieve him: who first ventures
To fetch it off is ours; I cannot see him,
He lies close in a hole above, I know it,
Gnawing upon his Anger: Ha! No, 'tis not he.

sp.speaker: 1 Sol.
sp.l: 'Tis but the shaking of the Boughs.

sp.speaker: Macer.
sp.l: Plague shake 'em, I'm sure they shake me soundly.
There.

sp.speaker: 1 Sol.
sp.l: 'Tis nothing.

sp.speaker: Macer.
sp.l: Make no noise, if he stir, a deadly Tempest
Of huge Stones fall upon us: 'Tis done, close, close.

sp.speaker: Cara
sp.l: Sleep still, sleep sweetly Child, 'tis all thou feed'st on;
No Gentle Britain near, no Valiant Charity
To bring thee Food; poor K 〈…〉 thou art Sick,
Extream Sick, almost grown wild for Meat,
And yet thy Goodness will not confess, nor show it;
All the Woods are double loin'd with Soldiers,
No way left us to make a Noble Escape;
I'll si●down by thee, and when thou wak'st,
Either get Meat to save thee, or lose my Life
I'th' Purchase: Good Gods comfort thee, Ha!
Courage my Boy, I have found Meat; look Hengo,
Where some Blessed Britain to preserve thee,
Has hung a little Food and Drink: Chear up Boy,
Do not for sake me now.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: O Uncle! Uncle! I feel I cannot stay long,
Yet I'll fetch it to keep your Noble Life.
Uncle I am heart-whole, and wou'd live.

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: Thou sha't long, I hope.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: But my Head, Uncle!
Methinks the Rock goes round.
Don't you hear the noise of Bells?

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: Of Bells Boy! 'Tis thy fancy,
Alas, thy Body's full of Wind.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Methinks, Sir, they ring a strange sad Knell,
A Preparation to some near Funeral of State.
Nay, weep not, my own sweet Uncle,
You will kill me sooner.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: O my poor Chicken!

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Fie, faint-hearted Uncle!
Come tie me in your Belt, and let me down.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I'll go my self, Boy.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: No, as you love me, Uncle.
I will not eat if I do not fetch it,
The danger only I desire, pray tie me.

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: I will, and all my Care hang over thee;
Come Child, my Valiant Child.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Let me down apace, Uncle,
And you shall see how like a Daw I'll whip it
From all their Policies; for 'tis most certain
A Roman Train, and you must hold me sure too,
You'll spoil all else; when I have got it Uncle,
We'll be as merry—

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: Go i'th' Name of Heaven, Boy.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Quick, quick Uncle, I have it. Oh!

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: What ail'st thou?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: O my best Uncle, I am slain!

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: I see ye, and Heaven direct my Hand.
Destruction go with thy Coward Soul.
How do'st thou Boy? O Villain! Villain! Villain!

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: O Uncle, Uncle! How it pricks me!
Am I preserv'd for this? Extreamly pricks me.

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: Coward, Rascal, Coward, Dogs eat thy Flesh.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: O! I bleed hard, I faint too upon't.
How sick I am; the Lean Rogue, Uncle—

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: Look Boy, I have laid him sure enough.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Have ye knockt his Brains out?

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: I warrant thee, from stirring more;
Chear up Child.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Hold my Sides hard, stop, stop, O wretched Fortune!
Must we part thus? Still I grow sicker, Uncle.

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: Heaven look upon this Noble Child!

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: I once hoped
I shou'd have liv'd to have met these bloody Romans
At my Swords point, to have Reveng'd my Father's,
To have beaten 'em. O hold me hard Uncle—

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: Thou sha't live still I hope, Boy.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: I wou'd live a little longer;
Spare me Heavens, but only to thank you
For your tender Love. Good Uncle,
Good Noble Uncle weep not.

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: O my Chicken! My Dear Boy! What shall I loose—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Why a Child that must have Dy'd however,
Had this escaped me, Feaver, or Famine:
I was Born to Die, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: But thus unblown, my Boy.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I shall go the streighter my Journey to the Gods:
Sure I shall know when you come, Uncle?

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: Yes, Boy.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: And I hope we shall enjoy together
That Great Blessedness you told me of?

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: Most certain, Child.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: I grow Cold, my Eyes are going.

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: Lift 'em up.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Pray for me, and, Noble Uncle, when my
Bones are Ashes, think of your little Nephew. Mercy.

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: Mercy, you Blessed Angels take him.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Kiss me, so farewel, farewel.

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: Farewel the Hopes of Britain,
Thou Royal Graft, farewel, farewel:
Time, and Death, you have done your worst.
Fortune, now see, now proudly pluck off this Veil
And view thy Triumph: Look, look
What thou hast brought this Land to;
O Fair Flower! How lovely yet thy Ruins show!
How sweetly, even Death embraces thee.
The Peace of Heav'n; the Followship of all.
Great Souls be with thee.

div.stage: Enter Suetonius, Petilius, with Roman Soldiers,

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: Yield thee, bold Caratach; by all the Gods, I swear,
As I'm a Soldier, as I envy thee,
I'll use thee like thy self, th' Valliant Britain.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.l: Brave Soldier, yield:
Thou Stock of Arms and Honour!
Thou filler of the World with Fame and Glory!

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: Excellent Britain, do me but that honour;
That more to me than Conquest, that true happiness
To be my Friend.

sp.speaker: Car.

Suetonius, view this little Cas 〈…〉,

These Tears. I sacrifice to thee, my Boy!
But to my Queen, and my unhappy Country,

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: O thou too envy'd Miracles of Worth!
What bast thou done? Nas Rome, too poor a Mistress,
To Wed thee to her Arms? Not one Charm
In all her Courting Smiles, and Proffer'd Lawrels?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Rome, Sir. ah, no! She bids a Price too small,
To Bribe me into Life: my bleeding Country
Calls me to Nobler. Wreaths; and in her Fall,
To mount a Star in Albion's long, long Night:
And when her Caratach dies in such a Cause,
A British Tomb, outshines a Roman Triumph.

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: Prodigious Virtue!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Out-live my Country's Liberty!
Shall Caratach dare but to think that Thought!
Now Britain is all yours; but as my Blood,
From this small Fountain flows, grant me one Favour:
Lay this Young British Rose, Cropt in the Bud,
Close by my side; and since the World▪ your own,
Spare us but Earth enough to cover o'er
These small Remains, and I shall ask no more.

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: That Hollow'd Relick! Thou Rich Diamond!

div.head: EPILOGUE
div.byline: Spoken by Miss. DENNY CHOCK, But Six Years Old.

lg.l: WELL, now to speak a Good Word for the Play,
Dear Gallants, but alass, What can I say?
I am too Young for your kind Smiles to pray.
When we ask Favours, Naughty Men, from you,
We must be Old enough to grant 'em too.
Old! Pray how Old! O Yes, our Cupid's Darts
Must first be Feather'd, e're we shoot at Hearts;
But these weak Eyes, too feeble Charms; 'tis true,
You may look Babies there, but that won't do;
We must be able to make Babies too.
Who knows what Charms I have? I hear
A Gentle Story whisper'd in your Ear,
Has that strange power, nay, Sirs, if that will get ye,
You'll find that I can prattle very pretty,
You heard me t'other Day in Young Queen Betty.
Such Honey-words, such dear soft words I'll call,
Say such fine things, if saying will do all:
Ah no, the soft white Birds that sing to you,
Must be grown up to Bill as well as Cooe,
And I'm too small to win your Hearts that way,
But tho' I'm yet too Young for Turtles play,
By your warm Suns a Blooming Flower I'll grow,
And keep my Rose-bud, for your Smiles to Blow.
